_exec_summary.SummaryText:
City of Amarillo
River Road Water Reclamation Plant
RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.0	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant is committed to the safety of our workers, the public, and the environment. The resources invested in the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances demonstrate this commitment. The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant implements reasonable controls, such as training of personnel and the safe design, installation, operation and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to make every effort to prevent the release of hazardous substances but in the event of a release, our trained personnel will coordinate with local emergency response agencies and first responders to control and contain the release in a manner that will be safe for workers and will help prevent injuries to the public or the environment.

2.0 Description of The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant and Regulated Substances

The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant handles two substances regulated by the Risk Management Plan Rule (RMP Rule) in quantities above the Threshold Quantity. These substances are:

* Chlorine - stored in 1 ton cylinders and used for disinfection of the water.
* Sulfur dioxide- stored in 1 ton cylinders and used for dechlorination of water.

3.0 Hazard Assessment

The RMP Rule requires The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant to perform a Hazard Assessment of the regulated substances stored and used in the covered processes at the facility. This Hazard Assessment includes an offsite consequence analysis for the following scenarios:

* One worst-case and one alternative release scenario for each of the toxic substances sulfur dioxide and chlorine used in the disinfection and dechlorination of effluent at the facility. The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant completed a Hazard

Assessment for the covered processes and the results have been appropriately communicated to the local emergency response agencies. The Hazard Assessment has been recently updated to reflect changes in population.

4.0 Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The RMP Rule requires that a prevention program be established for The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant disinfection process. The following details the prevention program elements at The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant that apply to these processes.

4.1 Safety Information

The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to help ensure safe operation of The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant processes. Safety data sheets (SDSs) document the physical and chemical properties of hazardous substances handled at The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant, including chlorine and sulfur dioxide used in the covered process. The engineering design documents include the operating parameters, the design basis and configuration of the equipment in each covered process, and references to applicable codes and standards. 
	
4.2 Hazard Review

The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant performs and periodically updates hazard reviews of the covered processes to help identify and control process hazards. Checklists are used to guide the hazard review. These checklists include items to help ensure The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant operates and maintains the equipment in a manner consistent with the applicable design specifications, codes, standards, and regulations.

4.3 Operating Procedures

The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant develops and maintains operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operations should be performed. The operating procedures are used to:

1. train employees and contr

actors, and
2. serve as reference guides for appropriate actions to take during both normal and abnormal process conditions.

4.4 Training

The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant trains personnel in the operating procedures to help ensure safe and effective performance of their assigned tasks. A record of all training is maintained to help ensure new and refresher training is provided on a timely basis.

4.5 Maintenance 

The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant properly maintains the equipment in our processes. The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant maintenance program includes:

1. procedures to safely guide workers in their maintenance tasks,
2. worker training in the maintenance procedures, and
3. inspection and testing program to help identify equipment deterioration and damage before equipment fails.

4.6 Compliance Audits

The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant performs periodic (at least every three years) audits of covered processes to verify the processes are operating in compliance with the requirements of the RMP Rule. A compliance audit report is prepared after each audit, and any deficiencies noted by the audit are corrected in a timely manner.

4.7 Incident Investigations

The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment. The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant trains employees to identify and report any and all incidents requiring investigation. An investigation team is assembled and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident. The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate process enhancements are implemented.

4.8 Chemical-specific Prevention Steps  Process chemicals

Industry standards are followed at The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant to help ens

ure safe handling of process chemicals. The vendor supplies chlorine and sulfur dioxide via a Department of Transportation (DOT) approved truck and in DOT approved 1 ton cylinders. The process equipment is designed and constructed with state-of-the-art materials and technology utilizing the standards and guidelines of the Chlorine Institute, American Water Works Association, ASME, ANSI, and other applicable codes. Workers who perform operations involving chlorine and sulfur dioxide receive training emphasizing safe handling procedures according to the guidelines required by The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant.

5.0 Five Year Accident History
There has been 1 accident on July 3, 2021 in the sulfonation process that resulted in an injury to an employee at The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant in the past five years. The public and environment were not affected. 

Findings
1. During the investigation it was identified that James had no formal training. When asked he stated he was told to hold your breath and get away He also stated it was explained to him if your smell goes away, your gone. There are no records of training records for the employees at the facility.

2. When maintenance plans and schedules were discussed, there is a Maintenance Program in place but not used to full potential. RRWWTP stated the program was out of date and could not be updated. Follow up visit to IT showed this was correct the current program cannot be updated with the design of the current program set up. But the system can be used as it is currently set up, just no updates can be done. Maintenance records kept in logbooks at the work sites not centrally controlled.

3. The valve that failed was installed during the upgrade 3-4 years ago, when questioned on maintenance schedule on this piece of equipment. Manpower and Software were discussed. The plant previously had 4 mechanics and one electrician. Currently 2 on staff, which work 4 ten hours sh

ift, giving them Fridays off.

4. During the initial walk around, the PPE box in the Dechlorination room was found to be lacking respiratory protection, (picture 9). The PPE that was in place was not adequate for the job. Face shield on top of the locker was dirty and does not look like it has been used. It was also identified that there are no SCBSs at the location, full face respirators are on location, but no Respiratory protection plan or fit testing in place for the facility.

5. There is a SOP that is in place at the worksite that is detailed and covers most of the aspect of doing the job required. This was one instance where the SOP did not cover what was needed, there was no troubleshooting procedures in place. (Pictures 10,11,12 and 14)

6. Plant maintenance team understands that if a valve is hard to open, secure and notify supplier of this. Difficult valves are not supposed to be opened; it was discussed in the interviews that this is accepted practice. No documentation found during interviews for this. A separate SDS from Praxair, list valve difficulty in Section 7

7. James has been on the job approximately 3 months, he told me his benefits kicked in this weekend was the reason he knew that. The other operator has been on the job approximately 1 year.

8. No JSA or risk assessment in place for this operation. There are two JSAs showing the in intranet for RRWWTP. There are detailed SOP but does not cover all aspects of the job and potential hazards.

9. SDS was in place in the SOP binder (picture 10 and 12) this SDS identifies that an emergency eye wash and shower need to be in the area, there is a pressurized water wash down system in the building.

10. More than one person made that statement it will happen if you work around it. This was at this facility and one other that I spoke to about this to get some background information. Finding is, it is an acceptable hazard to the work force.

11. The Antero software that is used for the maintenance licen

se support expired on February 28, 20201. Training options are as follows On-line - $200/hr. These can have unlimited number of attendees and are live. The sessions are recorded, and you receive copies of the sessions. On-site Training - $1,500.00/first day, $1,200.00 for each additional day, plus travel expenses, after the license fee is paid. Osage WTP paid the support fee in the past, it increased to 4000.00 for renewal this year, the fee was discussed and with the lack of support for log in, change of maintenance tickets, and update issues due to the age of Citrix server application Antero was not able to be updated and Osage and River Road both stated the program was not user friendly, it was not renewed. IT confirmed the updating issues with the program. The other plants did not know the other was using the program, Osage spoke about the difficulty in getting log in for employees due to turnover with the previous log in, due retiring or leaving the City.

12. Cell phones are the primary means of communication for the employees on the plant. Radios are provided, staff said there is a lot of cross traffic. One reason they do not use, second reason some areas of the plant you cannot get signals in and out.

13. Reviewed a few different SDS for this chemical, there are different precautions depending on the supplier. Praxair, link is supplied, Brenntag is not available online without creating a log in to access the SDS, this is the supplier we use. Making the SDS to get hard, the SDS supplied by RRWWTP was outdated, the supplier was contacted and an updated SDS was supplied. Copy emailed to RRWWTP.

14. There was some hesitation to call the on-call mechanic, the staff explained the RR mechanic is on call one week then the Central Maintenance team is on call the next and it rotates like this. This is the reason why Michael Givens was called instead of the mechanic on shift, as it was not the RR mechanic due to the rotation. As Michael understands the plant better.

15. The space can be considered a confined space with the way the set up and the properties of the gas, there are two entry points. As this chemical is heavier than air and on a calm day it will settle and be retained by the concrete barriers in place with limited opens to allow for the gas to disburse quickly. The weather on the night of the release was wind speed 8.5 MPH and 100% humidity which would have kept the gas contained for a longer time frame inside the barriers.

6.0 Emergency Response 

The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant has prepared a written emergency response/action plan that complies with the RMP Rule, other federal standards and industry guidelines.  This plan has been communicated to the Local Emergency Planning Committee LEPC/EMA and local fire department under the coordination rules of the RMP.

7.0 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant continuously attempts to improve the safety of our processes to protect our employees, the public and the environment. The City of Amarillo River Road Water Reclamation Plant incident investigations, employee suggestions and improvements in technology are utilized to update the safety aspects of the processes.
